subject: Re: [junit] Error on TestCase subclass in Eclipse 1.0
msgSnippet: I think you have to override the constructor also in your test case. MyTestCase(String arg) The problem you are hitting is because there is no default
messageBody:
I think you have to override the constructor also
in your test case.

MyTestCase(String arg)

The problem you are hitting is because there is
no default constructor for the TestCase class.
It must be a compile time error. If you look at your
tasks you must have a compile time error.


--- Mark Tucker <mtucker@...> wrote:
>
> I am using Eclipse 1.0 with JUnit, but when I create
> my TestCase subclass, I get an error on that line
> that states:
>
> "The constructor junit.framework.TestCase() is not
> visible"
>
> I am using JUnit 3.7.
>
> Here is my code:
>
>
> package junit.samples.money;
>
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
>
> public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
>
> }
>
>
> A more detailed dump of the error is:
>
> java.lang.Error: Unresolved compilation problem:
> The constructor junit.framework.TestCase() is not
> visible
>
> at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Native
> Method)
> at
>
junit.samples.money.MyTestCase.<init>(MyTestCase.java:5)
> at java.lang.Class.newInstance0(Native Method)
> at java.lang.Class.newInstance(Unknown Source)
> at
>
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.getTest(RemoteTestRunner.java:145)
> at
>
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.getTest(RemoteTestRunner.java:134)
> at
>
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:187)
> at
>
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner.java:116)
> at
>
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner.java:68)
>
>
> Thanks,
>
> Mark
>
